title: Hand Mirror Decorated With the Ten Avatars of Vishnu
content:
accession_no_csv: 2016-00124

  Image: 

  object_work_type: hand mirrors

  title_text: Hand Mirror Decorated With the Ten Avatars of Vishnu

  preference: main

  title_language: 

  creation_date: 1800 - 1899

  creation_place_original_location: India
 South

  inscriptions: 

  inscription_language: 

  shape: irregular

  materials_name: ivory (material) bone (material)

  techniques_name: forming (physical activity)

  object_colour: multicoloured

  physical_appearance: The hand mirror is beige in colour
 with a white mirror. The handle of the hand mirror is smaller than its head. There are floral patterns and intertwining branches on the front and back of the handle. On the other side behind the mirror
 there is a carving of the Hindu deity Vishnu in a standing position. He is located in the centre
 and surrounded by the smaller images of his ten avatars. There are some scratches on the surface of the mirror.

  subject_terms_1: dowries carvings (visual works) deities ornaments (object genre) Hinduism floral patterns avatara

  subject_terms_2: Hand mirrors Avatars (Religion) Hinduism Dowry Vishnu (Hindu deity)

  subject_terms_3: NA Hinduism

  sgcool_label_text: Elaborate and ornamental objects such as this rare ivory hand mirror were not meant for everyday use. They were created as luxury accessories
 and were often included in dowries. While the handle is decorated with flowers and intertwining branches
 the back of the mirror is carved with the Dashavatar or ten avatars of Vishnu; a standing Vishnu is placed within an oval frame
 surrounded
 in anti-clockwise direction are the ten avatars.

metadata.title_text: Hand Mirror Decorated With the Ten Avatars of Vishnu
metadata.physical_appearance: The hand mirror is beige in colour, with a white mirror. The handle of the hand mirror is smaller than its head. There are floral patterns and intertwining branches on the front and back of the handle. On the other side behind the mirror, there is a carving of the Hindu deity Vishnu in a standing position. He is located in the centre, and surrounded by the smaller images of his ten avatars. There are some scratches on the surface of the mirror.

metadata.subject_terms_2: Hand mirrors Avatars (Religion) Hinduism Dowry Vishnu (Hindu deity)
metadata.sgcool_label_text: Elaborate and ornamental objects such as this rare ivory hand mirror were not meant for everyday use. They were created as luxury accessories, and were often included in dowries. While the handle is decorated with flowers and intertwining branches, the back of the mirror is carved with the Dashavatar or ten avatars of Vishnu; a standing Vishnu is placed within an oval frame, surrounded, in anti-clockwise direction are the ten avatars.
